Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
California State University, Dominguez Hills is offering $10,000 scholarships to 30 juniors and seniors majoring in biology, chemistry, mathematics, or physics to become science-math teachers in high-need secondary schools in the Los Angeles Unified School District. Noyce scholarships are increasing the number of graduates from CSUDH's science-math credential program and offer financial incentives to attract students, a large percentage of whom are underrepresented minorities, into teaching because many low-income, first-generation college students face daunting economic barriers. While holding a job, they attempt a full course load in science-math, and many experience delays. Noyce scholarships ease their financial burden and enable them to complete their degrees without delays caused by financial hardship.

CSUDH's Noyce Phase I was successful in reducing the time to earn a degree for students who entered as juniors, meeting recruitment goals, retaining all scholars in the program, and providing high-quality teachers to low-income schools. Thus, the Noyce Phase II project retains the project structure with enhancements, which include 1) more focus on recruiting chemistry and physics majors due to the need in LAUSD, 2) mentoring by Noyce Phase I graduates, Noyce Master Teaching Fellows and Noyce seniors, 3) more structured clinical experiences for scholars in science-math teaching in CSUDH's innovative lab school and 4) pre-recruitment of interested freshmen and sophomores through creative partnerships with community colleges.

The Noyce project is operating in cohorts, led by advisors from the colleges of Education and Natural and Behavioral Sciences. Scholars are attending monthly cohort meetings in conjunction with a lab school for peer and faculty support, advising, mentoring, information, and exposure to teaching experts. Through the cohorts, scholars are linked to academic resources, financial aid or other assistance they need. Nearly all Noyce scholars transition into the Transition to Teaching (TTT) accelerated teaching program, enabling them to earn their credential in one year while holding a full-time teaching position as a university intern in a high-need LAUSD school. TTT also provides substantial support in cohorts, leading to high retention. The Noyce Phase II project leverages 1) the innovative, federally funded TTT, accelerated credential program, 2) the NSF Noyce Master Teacher Fellows program and 3) the state-funded undergraduate recruiting program for science-math teachers. In combination, the Noyce, TTT and TEACH grants are providing three years of financial support during the last two undergraduate years and one year of post-baccalaureate teacher training. The evaluation is examining the impact of the Noyce Scholarship program on: 1) Phase I Noyce scholars in terms of their performance as teachers, their completion of the teaching requirement and their retention in the teaching profession; 2) The effectiveness of Phase II Noyce scholars as measured by their performance in the classroom; 3) The effectiveness of Phase II Noyce scholars as measured by their impact on student learning; and 4) Departments and the institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of California State University Dominguez Hills' (CSUDH's) Noyce Scholar Phase II Project (NSPII) was to increase the number of qualified secondary science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) teachers who teach in high-need school districts for at least four years after receiving their teaching credentials. Over the course of the grant the number of undergraduates involved in and supported by the project exceeded the original target of 30 and reached 37 although 4 ultimately withdrew. 33 undergraduate scholars were supported in acquiring teaching experience as support assistants in local high-need districts allowing them to develop a deep understanding of the teaching profession in the context of underserved communities. Of the 33 scholars, 10 earned teaching credentials and are currently teaching and 12 are enrolled in credential programs. Noyce alumni (6) and key program staff/leadership (2) were interviewed to understand their perspectives on program successes and challenges. Interview results suggest that the model?s impact is due to scholars gaining practical teaching experience as undergraduates, years before they are even in credential programs. Additionally, the model provided a high level of individualized support plus funding, which gave scholars time to study and stay on track toward graduation. Finally, a key success of the program was that all scholars were from underrepresented groups in STEM fields (i.e., all were from racial or ethnic minority groups or were female). In some cases, scholars were from the communities they eventually taught in offering deep understanding of high-needs schools and students and positive models of success for their students. These factors worked in concert to achieve the broader impact of a more diverse and well-prepared teaching force in STEM fields in high need districts.

Early Teaching Experience

Alumni and program leadership/staff agreed that practical classroom experience, so early in a future teacher's training (i.e., as an undergraduate), was one critical component of NSPII. For several alumni, practical experience helped them understand early what kind of teacher they wanted to be. One alumnus stated, "It gave me - it exposed me to different types of schools. Middle school and high school. And it made me realize where would be best for me." Additionally, scholars developed teaching skills as support assistants, which positioned them well as first year teachers: "So because I was able to work at so many different schools, I went to TA for so many different teachers, I was able to see what I felt they did right and what they did wrong. And being able to see that I was able to take it and adapt so that I can be better for my class." Program staff/leadership agreed that Noyce scholars working as first year teachers performed like veteran rather than novice teachers saying, "They actually begin to have an impact as soon as they become teachers of record, because of those years of classroom experience during their years of undergraduate education."

Individualized Support and Funding

Another lesson learned from project implementation was that individualized support coupled with funding allowed several scholars to overcome challenges and focus on their studies to successfully complete the program. For some scholars just knowing that someone was able to help them, made the difference. One person stated, "Just having a great team to support me. To answer any kind of question that I had, or they just, they find a way to help you no matter what." Other scholars noted the valuable support network in their fellow scholars and program staff/leadership that endured beyond graduation. Another scholar noted the financial contribution made it possible for him/her to focus on teaching, "If they weren't paying me to be a TA, I would've been working somewhere else and I wouldn't have gotten that experience." Holistic, individualized support was needed to help scholars graduate from CSUDH and enroll and succeed in a credential program to become highly prepared first year teachers.

Diverse Scholars from High Needs Communities

All Noyce participants were from racial or ethnic minority groups and/or were female. Some participants ended up serving as support assistants in the communities where they had attended school. This was extremely effective as stated by a program staff/leadership team member, "So you don't have to convince them to teach at a high needs school, they came most likely from a high needs school. They understand the community, they were raised in the community, they fully understand ... what the needs are and what it takes to have an impact at a high needs school, within the communities that they came from. That adds to the power of the cycle." The scholars also provided a model for their students who can see an example of someone from their community who became a successful teacher.
